citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A grey and white alpaca has severely overgrown hooves. The right front and left hind hooves are most significantly
impacted. However, the hooves on all four feet are so long that they are curling inwardly or outwardly. The right front is so
severely impacted that the inside digit has hyperkeratinization (thickening) of the pad. Each exhibitor shall establish and
maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, and treat
diseases and injuries. Hooves need to be trimmed as often as necessary to prevent overgrowth that can lead to pain,
injury, and/or gait abnormality.

There are two areas around the east gate of an enclosure housing four dromedary camels that have sharp points. The
fence material is wrapped around two large posts but the cut wire ends of the fence are not wrapped or cut off causing
sharp points the entire length of both approximately 8' fences. There is also an area on the north fence, the top wire
making up the fence, that has come unwrapped or has broken causing sharp points.
The outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals
from injury and to contain the animals.
Ensure that all housing facilities are constructed and maintained to protect the animals from injury.

-The outdoor portion of an enclosure housing five sheep has excessive feces. The only area without excessive feces is
within the shelter.
-The primary enclosure for thirteen goats, one zebu, and three cows contains four shelters. The shelters have
approximately 10’’ of manure pack (combination of manure and bedding).
-The primary enclosure for four dromedary camels has a shelter inside the barn. The sheltered area has approximately
10’’ of manure pack (combination of manure and bedding).
Excreta shall be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals
contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors.
The licensee admitted that these shelters have excessive build-up and need to be cleaned out. Excess manure and
soiled bedding must be removed from primary enclosures.

The primary enclosure housing four llamas and four zebu has approximately 8-10 rolls of fence and approximately 12
fence posts in it.
Premises (buildings and grounds) shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals from injury.
Accumulations of excess building materials must not be stored inside animal enclosures.
To be corrected by April 20, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a family member.
Additional Inspectors:
JUSTINE O MALLEY, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
